Ukraine – conflict ETC Situation Report #35 Reporting period: 01/05/2024 to 31/05/2024

The Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) was activated in Ukraine on 03 March 2022 following the escalation of armed conflict between Ukraine and the Russian Federation. ETC SitReps are distributed monthly.

Highlights

The ETC coordinated two Telecommunications Security Standards {TESS+} training sessions which took place from 13 to 17 May and from 20 to 24 May with 36 participants from 12 UN agencies. The objective of the training was to build capacity and provide in-depth induction into UN security communications systems (SCS) for technical UN personnel. Participants gave positive feedback, noting critical new practical skills which will help organize their work in the field offices of UN agencies, especially in regions where UN operations and missions are particularly active. Two telecommunications Security Standards The deployment of network firewall equipment {TESS+} training sessions were held in Kyiv for UN agencies. Photo: WFP/ETC donated by partner—Cisco Crisis Response―to support and secure the VHF radio network in Ukraine was completed in May. This has improved the security of the VHF radio network as well as real- time monitoring of all the remotes sites including Odesa, Mykolaiv, Dnipro, and Kharkiv. The only remaining site is Kramatorsk, where security challenges has entirely restricted access. The ETC will deploy the network equipment in Kramatorsk once the security situation is improved there.

From 07 to 08 May, in response to an urgent request from local authorities in Odesa, the ETC set up temporary internet connectivity services for registration points and tents in Odesa opened by the local authorities for support to people affected by intensified shelling. The ETC used its existing Remote Site on Vehicle (RsoV) and satellite solutions to deliver the service. By 09 May, all community members were registered using the new network and the ETC service concluded.

Situation Overview

In 2024, Ukraine has faced intensified attacks, resulting in increased civilian casualties and devastation in front-line areas and across the country, notably in the northeast.

On 14 May, speakers at the Security Council meeting condemned the intensified attacks on Ukraine’s civilian infrastructure which has caused extensive damage to energy facilities, compromising water supply in certain areas, and disrupting electricity access for millions of civilians.

Attacks on the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant continue and are causing major safety concerns. Two hydroelectric power plants in Ukraine have been decommissioned following a major attack on 08 May.

The International Organization for Migration (IOM) reports that approximately 3.39 million people have become internally displaced in Ukraine as of 31 March 2024. According to the United Nations High

Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC)

www.ETCluster.org
---
Page 2 of 5

Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), as of 14 March, approximately 6.5 million refugees from Ukraine are recorded globally.

The humanitarian community estimates that 17.6 million people in Ukraine—40 percent of the country’s total population—and 4.2 million in refugee-hosting countries continue to need multi-sectoral humanitarian assistance.

Impact on telecommunications

The TV tower in Kharkiv, which was destroyed during a strike on 22 April, is planned to be restored only after the end of hostilities.

Throughout May, the Ukrainian Broadcasting, Radiocommunications & Television Concern (BRT) continued to prioritize the restoration of sites where tower infrastructure was damaged by airstrikes between 16 to 22 March.

Continuing reports highlight significant disturbances to mobile and satellite telephony services in regions close to the frontlines.

Cyberattacks persist with varying impacts, affecting service availability in some cases, and targeting the unauthorized release of data in others. In May, Ukraine's Kyivstar allocated US$90 million to deal with the aftermath of the major cyberattack on telecommunications infrastructure that occurred in December 2023, which damaged infrastructure and disrupted mobile phone signals for millions of Ukrainians.

ETC Activities Coordination

The ETC coordinated two Telecommunications Security Standards {TESS+} training sessions which took place from 13 to 17 May and from 20 to 24 May with 36 participants from 12 UN agencies. The objective of the training was to build capacity and provide in-depth induction into UN security communications systems (SCS) for technical UN personnel. Participants gave positive feedback, noting critical new practical skills which will help organize their work in the field offices of UN agencies, especially in regions where UN operations and missions are particularly active. A video will be released on the training soon.

Security communications (radio)

VHF radio network

Equipment is being procured to expand the VHF radio network across eight priority sites—Kehychivka, Kropyvnytskyi, Mykolaiv, Orly, Pokrovsk, Poltava, Sumy, and Zaporizhzhia. A preliminary technical assessment of these eight sites has been carried out. The collaboration with BRT aims to restore critical broadcasting services in affected areas and continue support in existing areas1.

A joint mission was held from 29 to 30 May to the BRT tower site in Sumy, which was severely damaged in airstrikes on 07 March. The ETC, UNDSS, and WFP confirmed that significant restoration of the site has taken place, and it is now ready to host the ETC’s VHF radio network.

The deployment of network firewall equipment donated by partner—Cisco Crisis Response―to support and secure the VHF radio network in Ukraine was completed in May. This has improved the security of the VHF radio network as well as real-time monitoring of all the remotes sites including Odesa,

1 Existing VHF radio coverage provides secure communications services beyond the common operational areas of Kyiv, Odesa, Dnipro, Lviv, and key locations close to the frontline in Kramatorsk, Kharkiv, Mykolaiv, Luch, and Kherson. Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) www.ETCluster.org
---
Page 3 of 5

Mykolaiv, Dnipro, and Kharkiv2. The only remaining site is Kramatorsk, where security challenges has entirely restricted access. The ETC will deploy the network equipment in Kramatorsk once the security situation is improved there.

During the power cuts experienced in Kyiv in May, the ETC verified the resilience of the power back-up system provided to the Remote Security Operations Centre (RSOC). The results and monitoring tools confirmed that the SOC radio and internet connectivity set-up remained operational throughout the power cuts. Similarly, mitigation actions were taken in Kharkiv on 21 May to improve the reliability of the security communications system during power cuts. The mission included upgrading the power back-up system for remote site equipment, which now can sustain up to 20 hours in case of a power cut.

The ETC raised the height of the VHF radio repeater antenna in Odesa to expand coverage within the city. Additionally, VHF coverage was assessed in the Odesa warehouse area where there is a repeater to seek recommendations to enhance base radio access. Unfortunately, there was no coverage improvement in the warehouse area after extending the antenna. Further actions are being explored.

Finally, the ETC resolved the VHF interference issues at the BRT radio repeater site in Dnipro.

Radio training & programming On 09 May, the ETC conducted two SCS training sessions for 20 UNICEF and 14 IOM personnel in Odesa.

On 30 May, UNHCR and ETC delivered SCS training for 15 IOM personnel in Chernivtsi.

To book security communications training sessions, please use this link. ETC radio programming services can be requested through a ticketing system via email: ukraine.etcservicedesk@wfp.org

Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) project

The ETC is working to establish a Long-Term Agreement (LTA) with a local supplier to standardize the procurement process and facilitate Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) procurement for the ETC and its partners in Ukraine. Offers have been received, and a technical evaluation is underway.

With ETC support, UNFPA has completed one Remote Site on Vehicle (RSoV) kit. The ETC will support with kit testing and user training. The UNFPA kit will be deployed in the eastern operational UNFPA sites in Ukraine and it will also be used for inter-agency convoys.

The ETC tested and deployed one WFP armoured vehicle RSoV kit and one OCHA armoured vehicle pre-cabled with RSoV to cover SCS needs for inter-agency missions in Kharkiv. The cluster trained WFP and OCHA personnel on how to operate the solution.

The RSoV pre-cabling of the 18th Logistics Cluster truck is finalized and tested.

Telephony Throughout May, the ETC conducted several tests on satellite phones in areas where they are used by humanitarians as part of the security communications system in Ukraine. Low reliability of the Iridium network in Kyiv, Dnipro, and Odesa has been escalated to the network provider by the ETC. Up to 10 attempts were needed to register and perform calls on the network.

2 During the project, the equipment has been deployed also in the UNDSS-managed primary SIOC in Kyiv and back-up Remote Security Operations Centre (RSOC) in Lviv. Emergency Telecommunications Cluster (ETC) www.ETCluster.org
---
Page 4 of 5

High reliability of the Inmarsat network was found on the road from Kyiv to Kharkiv. More tests are planned—the ETC will provide a final report and recommendations to UN partners on the use of Inmarsat satellite phones in Ukraine.

Secure data connectivity

The ETC continues to support data connectivity services in the inter-agency hubs in Odesa, Kharkiv, and Mykolaiv.

The ETC remains committed to safeguarding its connectivity services and employs advanced firewall protection implemented in collaboration with partner―Cisco Crisis Response.

Services for communities

From 07 to 08 May, in response to an urgent request from the local authorities in Odesa, the ETC set up temporary internet connectivity services for registration points and tents in Odesa opened by the local authorities for support to people affected by intensified shelling. The ETC used its existing RSoV and satellite solutions to deliver the services. By 09 May, all community members were registered using the new network and the ETC service concluded.

On 20 May, a field assessment was initiated by the ETC in shelters in schools in Yuzhne, Odesa, to determine the reported gaps in internet connectivity services. This comes in response to a request made in March by the Education Department to support this activity in the Odesa region.

In response to a request from the local authorities, a need for enhanced communication tools and internet connectivity was identified in the Mykolaiv region. The aim is to link mental health and rehabilitation centres with local medical and social services, particularly for the affected population including displaced persons in remote communities. Assessments are ongoing to establish telecommunications services to facilitate health care access and support. On 20 May, a meeting was held with local IT specialists in Mykolaiv regarding the network infrastructure.

Dashboard See the ETC Dashboard for an overview of service locations.

Funding

In 2024, the ETC in Ukraine has a budget requirement of US$1.5 million to continue to deliver vital communications services. The ETC is currently 73% funded out of this total with a US$1.1 million balance from funding received in 2023.

Funds received by the ETC in 2023 were carried over to complete critical projects, including US$921,000 received in May 2023 from the Government of Japan and a US$500,000 in-kind equipment donation received in February 2024 from Cisco Crisis Response to secure the VHF radio backbone network in Ukraine.

Challenges

The escalating security situation in eastern and southern areas of Ukraine hampers ETC efforts to expand the VHF network.

Data Collection

Objectives and Scope

Methodology

Findings

Learning

The review utilized a qualitative approach, drawing data from desk reviews and key informant interviews (KII).

Key informant interviews were conducted with representatives from various stakeholders, including national societies (NS), experts embedded in NS, C Movement partner stakeholders (BRC, IFRC, etc.), Cash Working Group co-chairs and partners, CashCap/NORCAP, and external stakeholders.

Interview questions were structured based on the team's review matrix.

The team surpassed the initial KII target, conducting 35 interviews instead of the planned 33.

Ukraine Syria Outsiders

Replicability

Conclusion and Recommendations

Limitations:

Measuring Impact: Difficulty in measuring impact due to the pilots' nature and lack of tangible outcomes. Findings heavily rely on interviewee perceptions. Timing of Review: Clarity on pilots' contribution to CashCap's localisation objectives will emerge once experts depart their contexts. Differentiating Pilot from Experts: Key informants struggle to provide unbiased feedback due to personal relationships with experts.
---
Findings
---
Findings Relevance

How relevant were CashCap's expert deployment and partner selection in pilot countries

While most interviewees were not aware of the rationale behind the selection in their country for the pilot, all informants in Syria and Ukraine considered the pilots to be extremely relevant to the contexts chosen.

The interest in CVA capacity-strengthening and the willingness to assume a leadership role in cash delivery was paramount for both NS. When coupled with their pivotal roles within their country, these elements underscore the relevance of the selected contexts.

The missions and objectives captured in the ToRs matched the requirements on the ground.

The BRC’s established rapport with SARC positively influenced the perception of the deployment's relevance as well as its effectiveness

The experts deployed successfully adjusted to the NS’ needs and priorities throughout their deployment, thus increasing the relevance of the pilots.

Examples of areas of focus not part of the initial ToRs: Syria: Focus on CVA earthquake response and coordination Ukraine: Focus on co-chairing the CWG

The ToR drafting process appeared to have been relatively opaque. This did not impact the effectiveness of the deployments, nor does it question their relevance per se.

Share of KI who know / don’t know why their country was selected for the pilot Don't know… Know 60%

A number of factors contributed to the perceived relevance of the deployment: the perceived neutrality of the expert, the length of deployment, and the interpersonal and technical skills of the experts deployed.
---
Findings

How effective were the pilots in supporting local and national organizations in the two contexts?

Effectiveness

Overall Effectiveness

• Technical expertise, interpersonal skills, and deployment duration significantly influenced the pilot's effectiveness. Experts' knowledge of cash coordination and extensive experience in cash and voucher assistance (CVA) were crucial. The duration of deployment, typically one to two years, allowed experts to grasp contextual nuances and ensure continuity, especially in Ukraine. Some RCRC interviewees noted experts' superior technical strength in CVA compared to delegates, leading to significant internal coordination roles.

Coordination and Advocacy

• Effective deployment positioned both SARC and URCS in external coordination forums, notably Cash Working Groups. • In Ukraine, URCS attained co-chair status in the CWG, facilitated by the expert's leadership and training efforts. • In Syria, SARC's external coordination strengthened, with increased collaboration within the CWG and improved negotiations with clusters. • The expert played a crucial role post- earthquake in Syria, enhancing the NS's visibility and understanding of external coordination mechanisms.

In turn, this positively contributed to the visibility and empowerment of both NSs, which is a direct outcome of localisation. Both SARC and URCS took on more significant roles in external coordination structures. Interviewees underscored that this enhanced their visibility and empowerment in the NSs.

While significant progress has been made in coordination, the extent to which it is sustainable remains to be seen.

One of the unintended positive outcomes of the pilot was the contribution to effective internal coordination between the NS and the Partner National Societies.
---
“Becoming co-chair gave URCS a push to up their game”

“SARC’s interaction with the CWG has changed significantly since the expert was deployed”

“SARC is the most active participant in the technical working group under the cluster system”

“Internal coordination massively improved in 2023 vs. 2022.”

“Being co-chair gave us visibility with donors and international organisations. Combined with the fact that we were a big cash actor, it gave us CVA legitimacy.”
---
Findings Effectiveness

How effective were the pilots in supporting local and national organizations in the two contexts?

Quality CVA at scale NS' ability to implement quality CVA at scale improved in both countries during the deployment period. Experts significantly contributed to this improvement, particularly in documentation development and information management enhancements. In Ukraine, despite progress, some interviewees feel the NS isn't fully cash ready, citing a gap in understanding at branch level and the absence of sectoral cash for URCS

Syria - Harmonizing CVA tools

- Integrating cash components into sectoral tools used by various departments within SARC

- Supporting CVA and Information Management (IM) departments within SARC in establishing the CVA database

- Contribution to the development of Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) for CVA and Livelihood activities

- Expert's crucial role during earthquake response, mobilizing full team within days and securing significant funding

Ukraine

- Implementation of a no-regret cash in envelope for 270,000 recipients for 2 weeks for the Ministry of Reintegration and Occupied Policy

- 100,000 recipients per month for host community members hosting IDPs between Sept 2022 and December 2023 (start of the program in June 2022)

- URCS as the sole partner of the government since September 2022, handling registration, payment, PDM, and CEA

- Voucher support to 50,000 people with PNS assistance

- Quality and accountable delivery ensured through adequate systems and procedures (verification, monitoring, CEA, reporting, Cash Platform, etc.)

- Transition from blanket approach to vulnerability targeted approach - MOUs established with government
---
Findings

How effective were the pilots in supporting local and national organizations in the two contexts?

Effectiveness

CVA skills and Competence • Experts significantly enhanced CVA skills and competence in both Syria and Ukraine, leading to substantial improvements. • All interviewees appreciated the experts' soft skills and mentoring approach. • Majority of interviewees noted the cash team's strong willingness to learn, contributing to positive outcomes. • Key elements for skill enhancement included daily teaching and mentoring, collective capacity-building activities, and quality feedback and reporting. • Challenges remain in turnover and sustainability, with staff turnover and "brain drain" common. • Debate arose regarding the expert's impact on improving capacities and systematic ways of working, particularly in SARC and Ukraine's CVA unit.

Evidence of Progress • Lack of clear objectives for experts before deployment and within host countries. • Limited awareness of overarching goals, as seen in Syria. • BRC established a work plan for experts in Syria, but many interviewees were unaware of it. • In Ukraine, Cash expert reported directly to Deputy Director of Programmes, addressing URCS priorities. • Despite the cash strategy in URCS One Plan 2023–2025, no detailed work plan was developed. • Absence of defined outcomes not viewed negatively by most KIs; seen as adaptable. • Challenges include determining deployment duration and devising exit strategies. • Missed opportunity in Ukraine to utilize Red Cross' CVA self- assessment tool for tracking progress.
---
Learning and Replicability
---
Learning

Objectives and Scope

Lessons Learned & Recommendations for Model Effectiveness and Future Scale-up

Methodology

Findings

Learning

Replicability

Conclusion and Recommendations

Exit Strategy

Extension of the pilot is crucial for consolidating capacity-strengthening efforts in Syria and Ukraine, with most interviewees advocating for at least another year, preferably two. Factors influencing duration and exit strategy include internal factors such as cash readiness and expert coaching approach, along with external factors like staff turnover and funding availability.

Challenges persist without baseline and endline assessments for decision- making. Insights for an effective exit strategy include progressive exit with remote coaching, light-touch reviews for recommendations, and a one-month handover between experts.

Learning about the pilot

• Interviewees, especially in National Societies (NSs), advocate for structured deployment with clearer objectives and increased involvement in expert selection. While agility in adapting to emerging needs is praised, about half suggest a more structured approach for future deployments. • Some NS interviewees emphasize the importance of interpersonal skills and seek involvement in setting objectives and expert selection. • Limited NS involvement was observed in drafting Terms of Reference (ToRs) and expert selection in Syria and Ukraine. In Ukraine, there's a proposal to involve NS and CashCap directly in decision-making and ToRs drafting, with regular partner check-ins.

Deployment facilitated significant knowledge exchange, benefiting both experts and CashCap. Initially not part of the review matrix, this aspect was added after discussions with Norcap, highlighting its significance in the context of localization. Experts, regardless of prior Red Cross exposure, shared examples of benefits, including enhanced internal coordination within the Movement and a deeper understanding of local actors' challenges in the humanitarian sector and NS role with the government in both countries. The pilot design and expert identification provided insights into the importance of selecting experts motivated for long-term roles with national actors and the need to adapt recruitment processes to screen for mentorship and 'leading from behind' qualities.
---
Replicability

Objectives and Scope

Methodology

Model Effectiveness and Future Scale-up Findings Learning Replicability

Conclusion and Recommendations

There was a consensus among interviewees globally, including in Syria and Ukraine, emphasizing the critical nature of deploying and embedding a CashCap expert within a National Society (NS), suggesting this model's effectiveness for future implementation in diverse contexts.

Justification for CashCap's involvement includes the requirement for local actors to either act as or have the potential to be key cash response entities, with less than a quarter of interviewees in Syria and Ukraine seeing potential for other local actors.

The embedment of an expert offers a unique value proposition for NSs, enhancing relevance and demonstrating replicability potential through expertise in large-scale CVA design and implementation, in-depth understanding of expectations and practices of other actors, neutrality compared to PNS CVA delegates, and proficiency in CVA coordination. While the first characteristic is not exclusive to CashCap experts, the combination of these attributes is deemed unique.

Replicability involves prioritizing NSs where deployment will be most effective, considering factors like large-scale emergencies with extended response durations and preparedness and anticipatory action where NSs play a pivotal role as government auxiliaries.
---
Replicability

Objectives and Scope

Methodology

Model Effectiveness and Future Scale-up Findings Learning Replicability

Conclusion and Recommendations

The main limiting factor to replicability is CashCap’s ability to deploy the right expert and to commit the expert for a minimum duration of one year • Minimum deployment duration favored by most interviewees: One year, allowing for operational readiness.Less than a year raises concerns about deployment value for about half of interviewees. • Interviewees from NSs and PNSs don't prioritize immediate deployment due to the understanding of time required for expert selection. Strong expectations exist for CashCap to send highly qualified experts

Mixed views within the Movement about the need for the expert to have experience working with the RC • Approximately one-third deem RC experience mandatory, while others prioritize relevant context and crisis experience alongside interpersonal and technical skills.

Regional Perceptions: • Perception consistency across countries despite varying expert RC experience. • Greater emphasis on RC experience in Ukraine due to crisis novelty and PNS coordination challenges. • Potential underrating of RC experience need in Syria due to SARC's embedment support from BRC.

PNS vs. NS Perspective: • PNS prioritize movement experience, while NS prioritize knowledge of external actors. • Suggestions for on-the-job coaching to mitigate lack of RC experience."
---
“It’s not that someone outside couldn’t bring value to it, but it definitively helps to have lived it.”

“Having Red Cross experience is not needed, but a “Red Cross induction” from the CashCapper to a new one would be useful (3 days training for example).”

“We overstate the importance of having movement experience to understand the movement. It’s much more about effective relationship management than understanding of it.”

“It should be mandatory to send someone with Red Cross experience.”
---
Conclusion and Recommendations
---
Conclusion

Objectives and Scope

The review demonstrated the relevance and effectiveness of this pilot and calls for the replication of the scheme in other contexts

Methodology

Findings

Learning

Replicability

Conclusion and Recommendations

Interviewees affirmed the effectiveness of deployment and integration within URCS and SARC, attributing it to expert skills, deployment duration, neutrality, and adaptability

Embedding a CashCapper presents a unique value proposition for NSs and local actors, showcasing technical expertise, soft skills, and adaptability

The pilot significantly boosted capacity, particularly in implementing quality CVA at scale and coordinating effectively

Sustainability challenges, especially in Ukraine, necessitate a gradual exit strategy with at least another year of deployment

Future replications should clarify CashCap's role with NSs and involve them in needs identification and expert recruitment for effective replication
---
Recommendations

Objectives and Scope

Methodology

Determine CashCap's annual deployment capacity based on available experts to prioritize target NSs effectively

Utilize self-assessment exercises by NSs' CVA units, when available, to measure deployment effectiveness and contribution to localisation, maintaining deployment adaptability without setting rigid objectives upfront

Explore a mixed deployment model spanning three years, with the expert's full- time presence in the first year, followed by shorter-term missions in subsequent years to enhance sustainability and continuity

Findings

Learning

Consider involving more NS/PNS actors in the expert selection process to increase accountability and ensure a participative approach in line with localisation principles

Consider a model where NSs contribute financially to deployments, demonstrating commitment to CVA preparedness and hosting the expert.

Explore setting up a system where NSs can apply for deployments, ensuring a participative approach. Develop eligibility criteria considering factors like cash readiness and contextual needs.

Replicability

Conclusion and Recommendations

Clarify CashCap's positioning towards NSs at their request: Is CashCap a partner communicating directly with NSs? Improve communication to ensure NSs are well-informed and create open channels for discussion.

Structure CashCap's support to NSs, including monitoring, to document lessons learned and benefits gained from expert deployments into NSs in future monitoring and evaluation (M&E) efforts.

When deploying an expert without RC experience, provide support to ensure a thorough understanding of movement functions for effective deployment.
---

The focused analysis of the 2023 MSNA on disability followed the recommended Washington Group Short Set (WG-SS)4 of questions, with a total of 1.853 individuals participating as a group of proxy respondents who were asked if any household (HH) member had visual, hearing, mobility, cognition, self-care, and communication difficulties. Based on data analysis, the

report presents an analytical comparison on three main strata: households with not reported disability in the household (HH- no-pwd), households with at least one member with reported disability 2 or above5 (HH-cut-off-2), and household with at least one member with reported disability 3 or above6 (HH- cut-off-3), as per the graphic below:

Profile & needs overview

This section discusses the demographic profile and outlines articulated needs of the interviewed households' members, including a comparison between the reported difficulties and the level of severity.

The assessment covered a total of 819 households (HH) with 1.853 members, of whom 36% of them reported at least one member with a disability level 2 or above and 13% of HH reported at least one individual with disability 3 or above. In addition, a total of 21% HH members reported disability 2 or above and 6% reported disability level 3 or greater.

Regarding the described difficulties across all age groups, the most cited were visual limitations, followed by mobility difficulties. A total of 58% of household members over 60 years old reported having more disabilities, mostly physical and visual problems. It is worth noting that, as per global data, more than 46% of older persons worldwide – those aged 60 years and over—reported having disabilities (see more on intersection of age and disability in conclusions).7

Among children, 10% reported to experience some kind of difficulty. The majority of those children reported difficulties with seeing (60%), while other reported difficulties with walking and communicating at relatively high level (17% and 15% respectively). As presented in the table below indicating distribution by age group of household members reporting disabilities, at any severity level, the majority of physical or mental impairments appear in the oldest age group.

Further in-depth analysis provides information on the different difficulties and the level of severity for each of them. Visual limitation was the most reported condition with a low level of severity, while remembering and self-dressing were less reported with a higher severity level.

Priority needs The 2023 MSNA highlighted specific priority needs for the refugees coming from Ukraine, including about access to healthcare services, employment and livelihoods, language courses, accommodation options, food and medicines. A comparative analysis of data between those HH with at least one member with disability and HH with no member with disability shows that slightly more priority needs were reported by the former group (between 86%-89%), compared to the latter (81%). While reported needs in the group with no members with disability were widely spread, the most cited priorities needs for HH with at least a person with disability were healthcare services and medicines. An interesting observation which needs to be further explored is the fact that accommodation and employment/livelihood was reported as a problem by less HH with disabilities than in those without members with disabilities. An explanation could be based on the provided support by the Government to those persons with disabilities under the Temporary Protection (TP) scheme.

4 Washington Groups Short Set (WG-SS), online 5 Disability level 2 or above: the level of severity of a difficulty reported by a person is “some difficulty”, "a lot of difficulty" or "cannot so at all". 6 Disability level 3 or above: the level of severity of a difficulty reported by a person is "a lot of difficulty" or "cannot do at all". 7 Ageing and disability | United Nations Enable https:/ /www.un.org/development/desa/disabilities/disability-and-ageing.html
---
Education

Enrolment of refugee children with disabilities or special needs in the formal education system continuous to be challenging in Slovakia. From the total HH interviewed, the sample for children with a disability remained too low to run an analysis and therefore secondary data and sources are used to provide some views in this regard.

The Rapid Situation Analysis and Needs Assessment of Ukrainian Children with Disabilities elaborated by the Platform of Families with Children with Disabilities informed that “(as Ukrainians) used to a more integrated school system back home, Ukrainian parents often aim to enroll their children with disability in a regular school. They are often surprised at the very low number of regular schools that integrate children with disability in Slovakia”.8 As the Platform further reported, “families may not disclose their child’s diagnosis in order to facilitate their enrollment in school or their integration in the wider society”. Additional information provided by the study presented important concerns frequently cited by parents regarding lack of disability-adapted early childhood and formal education capacities. In addition, bullying remains an important concern raised by parents of children with disabilities.

“…Lessons for kids with autism or other development disability are very expensive, you need all your salary, and sometimes is not enough …”

Parent of a child with autism, in a focus group discussion in Bratislava.

As per the most updated data provided by the Ministry of Education9 as of end of December 2023, a total of 96 refugee children from Ukraine were enrolled in formal education in special schools for children with special needs, compared to the total of 11.818 refugee children enrolled in formal education the academic year 2023/2024.

Protection

Differences were identified in the comparative analysis of the reported awareness of protection services in the area of residence. In general, HH with no person with a disability reported being more aware of protection services (mainly state social services), than those with a member with disability. Only awareness of psychosocial support services was slightly higher in HH with a member with disability 3. This outcome indicates a strong need for more targeted information provision focusing on specific disability-related services.

De facto use of social services is rather low; according to the Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs (MOLSAF) information, only 46 persons persons with specific needs, including persons with disabilities, were residents in social service facilities.10

Additional analysis on social cohesion presents possible tensions with the host community reported by respondents. In general, HH with a family member with a disability reported a slightly higher percentage of hostile behavior from the host community.

Rather positive results were received in relation to assistance provided, including on information for available services as well as in-kind support. Among the total number of HH with at least one member with disability (295), only between 14% and 17% of HH reported not having received any assistance in the last 3 months11. In terms of satisfaction, HH with a person with disability presents higher satisfaction levels, between 74% and 76%, and only between 6% and 8% of households with a member with disability reported dissatisfaction with the assistance received. Only between 6% and 8% of households with a member with disability reported dissatisfaction with the assistance received. The high satisfaction might be related to multi-purpose cash and material need assistance provision available for persons with disabilities, particularly provided by MOLSAF. According to the information provided by the Ministry, disability cash assistance was provided in 2023 to 1.308 TP holders in the overall amount of 506.284 EUR.12

8 Platform of Families with Children with Disabilities / UNICEF: Rapid Situation Analysis and Needs Assessment of UA Children with Disabilities and their Families - online 9 Ministry of Education: enrolment of children from Ukraine - online 10 Data provided by the Ministry of Labour, Social Affairs and the Family of SR upon reguest. 11 This refers to any kind of assistance provided by humanitarian actors, government, or other entities. 12 Data provided by the Ministry of Labour, Social Affairs and the Family of SR upon reguest.
---
In particular, respondents were asked if they encountered any challenges accessing information needed (including information on rights and entitlements, access to services). Generally, HH with a member with disability reported facing more challenges accessing information, mainly due to a lack of knowledge of available sources of information. That finding was also raised during focus group discussions with parents of children with disabilities. This can represent a challenge for humanitarian actors for diversification and better targeting of information provision, given that persons with disabilities and older people might have limited access to online tools provided e.g. through applications and web-portals and/or because, overall, do not have knowledge of using information and communications technology (ICT).

The area of access to information is also highlighted in the analysis of the Platform of Families with Children with Disabilities. According to the analysis, “…the government together with international and community-level organizations should address the informational barrier that carers face in access to healthcare, education, social benefits, etc. In an often-changing legislative environment, working on periodic and timely informational campaigns that target not only Ukrainian carers but also local practitioners and social workers assisting this demographic is crucial in making the already available services more accessible.”.13

With regards to awareness of available services to reach out to and the possibility to report cases of violence against children in the community, HH with a person with disability reported higher awareness on those services, between 97 and 99%, compared to HH without a person with disability (95%). In addition, between 69% and 73% of HH with a person with disability reported awareness on how to access gender-based violence services available in Slovakia, compared to the 73% reported by HH without a person with disabilities.

Economic vulnerability & livelihoods

Overall, persons with disability reported lower education level in comparison to those with no reported disability; higher percentage was obtained on secondary and vocational education on individuals with disability, and master’s degree was more cited by persons with no disability. No major difference was identified on the comparative analysis for high education level, such as Ph.D. and Grand Ph.D., as this level is quite rare. However, more than 75% of persons with disabilities reported having secondary or higher education level which could translate into a high level of employability in Slovakia.

In terms of employability, nearly a third of persons with less serious disability reported being out of the labor market, compared to those with no disability (i.e., persons with serious medical conditions, on parental leave or students), which is comparable to the overall situation in the European Union where the labour market participation of persons with disabilities still presents a challenge; only half of persons with disabilities are employed, compared to 3 in 4 persons without disabilities.14 Of the rest of the sample, the analysis presented higher results reported on employment on individuals with no disability.15

“…Persons with disabilities cannot work in many cases; they need extra cash assistance and support for example to cover the costs of prothesis, wheelchairs…”

Adult person during a focus group discussion in Opatovska Nova Ves

Information available from the focus groups discussions pointed out the challenges faced by caregivers in finding employment, particularly for mothers, which can revert on situations of isolation from the rest of the society. Additionally, families with children with a disability may face additional financial burden to provide for therapies, as presented in the analysis of the Platform of Families with Children with Disabilities:“…many families experience financial hardship due to the cost of care for their child with disability and are seeking extra income.”.16

NOTE: Employed are those of working age (15-64 years) who are employed, have their own business, or work in a family business; unemployed are those of working age (15-64 years) who are looking for work and at the same time are ready to start work within 14 days; outside the labor market are those of working age who do not fall into the above categories (typically persons with serious medical condition, on parental leave and students who do not work).

13 Platform of Families with Children with Disabilities / UNICEF: Rapid Situation Analysis and Needs Assessment of UA Children with Disabilities and their Families - online 14 European Commission; Employment, Social Affairs & Inclusion; Persons with disabilities - online 15 No analysis was run for HH members – cut-off 3 due to the low number of working-age HH members in this strata 16 Platform of Families with Children with Disabilities / UNICEF: Rapid Situation Analysis and Needs Assessment of UA Children with Disabilities and their Families - online
---
Regarding the social protection systems17, data show positive results on benefits coverage depending on the type of HH. In general, HH with a person with disability reported being benefited in a larger scale, while between 47% and 37% of HH with a person with disability reported being covered by the Slovak social protection system. This presents a significant difference compared to HH without members with disability (15%) which is easily understandable, as the Slovak social protection system is designed to support the most vulnerable groups, with a specific cash assistance to persons with disabilities. Similar results were obtained on the benefits received from the Ukrainian social protection system, however, only 4% of HH without a member with disability reported being covered by this assistance. This percentage differs in the case of HH with a person with disability, which represents between 17% and 14%.

“…Financial support related to disability in Slovakia is a complex and long-term process…”

Adult person during a focus group discussion in Trnava

The comparative analysis shows that HH with a person with disability tend to make less use of financial services, such as a bank account or an account at a formal financial institution in Slovakia. Between 76% and 70% of respondents reported using this kind of services, compared to the 80% of HH without a member with a disability. This would require a more focused analysis to see if there are some institutionalized challenges in the financial services (which might be a case of a discrimination in the provision of services and/or access to those services), or if persons with disabilities are less interested to use them.

In addition, regarding changes on the HH 2023 income compared to 2022, HH with a person with disability reported more negative balance, compared with the other type of HH.

Overall, regarding the analysis on food consumption, the majority of HH obtained an acceptable food consumption score (FCS)18 result with around 93% in the case of HH with a person with disability. Nevertheless, the comparison of borderline or poor food consumption score presented higher results on HH with a person with disability (7%), compared to the 3% in the case of HH without a member with disability.

In addition, with the aim to measure the hardship faced by HH due to a shortage of food, the survey included the Reduced Coping Strategies Index (RCSI)19 information, which measures the frequency and severity of food consumption behaviors the HH had to engage in due to food shortage in the 7 days prior to the survey.

Overall, regarding the situation of persons with disabilities in the European Union, over 28% of persons with disabilities are at risk of poverty or social exclusion compared to over 17% of persons without disabilities.20

Results from the comparative analysis in Slovakia presents that HH with a person with disability are more likely to adopt coping strategies, with special attention on crisis and emergency coping strategies, such as degrading source of income (illegal work or high-risk jobs), double compared to the other type of HH.

NOTE; At governmental level, refugees from Ukraine with severe disabilities and their caregivers can apply for humanitarian aid subsidy provided by the Ministry of Labour, social affairs, and family21. The degree of serious disability is assessed by social workers of the Ministry following a questionnaire based on WHODAS22. The humanitarian aid provided can be from 300 – 508 euros per month depending on the degree of severity (40-59% or 60% or more respectively).

Health Access to healthcare services was reported by HH as first priority need23, even higher for HH with a person with disability (see first part of this section). Moreover, the study shows healthcare needs were cited more in HH with person with disability, but also less challenges when accessing the required services.

17 Social protection system covers benefits (e.g. maternity leave, pensions, material need benefit (dávka v hmotnej núdzi)). 18 Food Consumption Score FSC: online 19 Reduced Coping Strategies Index (RCSI): online 20 European Commission; Employment, Social Affairs & Inclusion; Persons with disabilities - online 21 Ministry of Social affairs and family, Subsidy to support humanitarian aid to a person with special protection in connection with their serious disability: online 22 WHODAS – WHO Disability Assessment, measuring health and disability: online
---
Additional sources of information24 presents the lack of pediatric and specialized care as the main concern, together with the insufficient complementary health care and health aids coverage. Respondents also mentioned temporary visits to Ukraine for diagnostics, treatment or to seek health aids, due to the unavailability on accessing healthcare services in the country. Disrupted treatment, rehabilitation and daily routines are common concerns reported during focus group discussions, on top of the additional barriers faced by all refugees, such as language.

“…My daughter was receiving rehabilitation sessions in Ukraine. In Slovakia, we cannot cover the costs…”

Parent of a girl with disabilities during a focus group discussion in Nitra

Regarding mental health or psychosocial problems, differences were observed in the comparative analysis. Generally, more mental health and psychosocial problems were reported by HH with a member with disability (between 54% and 44%), compared to the 22% reported by those HH without a member with disability.

Accommodation

Results from the analysis reflected own accommodation25 as the most common type of accommodation cited by respondents at the time of the interview. The comparative analysis shows that HH with a person with disability 3 or above are less likely to stay in collective sites such as existing building (schools, community centers).

Additional information from the Site Mapping and Monitoring exercise26, including in particular data of 45% of the total collective sites surveyed in October 2023, reported not being accessible for persons with disabilities. Regarding the facilities at the sites, 35% of sites reported not having showers accessible and 47% in the case of shower facilities. In addition, 72% reported not having equipment for persons with disabilities and/or older persons such as wheelchairs, scratchers, etc. Overall, 35% of sites reported the need to be adapted for persons with disabilities.

Almost half of the respondents reported having secured tenure for a period of 6 months or more. The analysis shows HH with a person with disability reported less uncertainty compared to those without a person with disability, which can be explained on the need to secure an accessible space or which can be explained due to options on accommodation provided by authorities to HH with persons with disability.

Conclusions

The MSNA - Annex Report on persons with disability indicates that access to health is the top priority need reported by all type of households (HH), specially by those with a person with disability.27 However, those HH continue reporting also basic needs, such as for medicins and food, among priority needs. This highlights that, still, some of the basic needs are not met by refugees and in particular among HH with persons with disabilities. Considering that, as per the MSNA results, access to employment and language courses remain among the top priority needs for the overall refugee population, thus, the findings for those with disabilities indicates considerable needs in connection with their vulnerabilities.

In addition, it can be observed that HH with a person with disability are exposed to more vulnerabilities and challenges towards their inclusion in the host community. Children with vulnerabilities face major barriers in accessing education28, thus severely limiting their prospects of accessing lifelong learning and livelihoods opportunities. HH with a person with disability are more likely to adopt negative coping strategies (56% on HH with a person with disabilities, compared to 39% on HH without persons with disabilities), and are more at risk of economic vulnerability, such as lower income, lower employability and limited access to financial systems which may result in higher poverty rates and social exclusion.

Yet, HH with a person with disability presented less challenges in accessing the healthcare system; which it can be related to their need of using frequently this type of services, being more awared and familiarized with them, or living in an accommodation type where health services are provided (as Humenne). However, families often have to cover costs of these services, in addition to the provided assistance. Moreover, challenges on access to health services are still reported in connection to disruptment of treatments and language barriers, among others. Mental health and psychosocial problems remain critical, as half of the HH with a person with a disability reported such problems.

24 Rapid situation analysis of the needs of children with disabilities and their families from Ukraine; online 25 Own accommodation including rented apartments, houses, guesthouses, etc 26 Site Mapping and Monitoring; Joint initiative of UNHCR and IOM, supported by SHC, which aims to obtain updated information on the situation, priority needs and available services on the accommodation sites, to better inform humanitarian response; online 27 It will be important to follow this trend after September 2023, when the Ministry of Health expanded access to universal healthcare for all temporary protection holders from Ukraine. 28 Rapid situation analysis of the needs of children with disabilities and their families from Ukraine; online
---
Age and Disability

Persons with disabilities face a number of obstacles including attitudinal, environmental and institutional barriers preventing their full and equal participation in all aspects of life. Often older persons with disabilities are among the most adversely affected, facing further age barriers in society.28

The intersection of aging and disability is a multi-faceted topic that impacts individuals, society, and service delivery. The experience of disability and aging is multi-factorial and dependent on wider social, cultural, structural, and environmental factors. As such, examining the connections between disability and aging may contribute to more nuanced understandings to improve well-being and quality of life and enhance service provision.29

Improvement of the accessibility to information on refugee rights for the different types of difficulties, including official sources, remains an important gap in the response. Some good examples are oberserved on websites with “read aloud” functionality, such as the initiative “From Ukraine to Slovakia”30. However, a further in-depth survey would be necessary to understand the hindrances HH with a member with disabilities may be facing in the access to information. This might also indicate isolation and a lower level of inclusion in local communities, which is unfortunately the case in the domestic population as well.

In addition, better planning and responses requires official disaggregated data on refugees with disabilities, on needs, barriers, additional cost of living, as well as the available support and type of participation and inclusion opportunities of children, adolescents and persons with disabilities. In this connection, apart of the sectoral information on education and health, it is critical to facilitate evidence-based planning for humanitarian actors and other stakeholders.

Many of those priorities are reflected in the UKRAINE SITUATION REGIONAL REFUGEE RESPONSE PLAN 2024 for Slovakia. The strategic objective 2 calls for action so that “Refugees with specific needs and vulnerabilities have access to targeted support and assistance.” A tailored and inclusive approach is followed by RRP partners which continue to complement the government-led efforts, working with experts in the field for the protection and assistance to persons with specific needs, and build capacity for specialized services and support, along with an increased access to information about these services. RRP partners will continue engaging based on the key principles of disability inclusion: (i) non-discrimination; (ii) awareness; (iii) participation; and (iv) accessibility. In addition, cooperation will be further promoted with national and local organizations working with persons with disabilities, as well as municipalities to ensure that initiatives and good practices can be further supported within local communities.

1. Purpose of this document

The purpose of this document is to compile in one place the necessary information for planning, monitoring, and reporting Shelter Cluster Activities included in the HNRP 2024. It describes the intended outcome for each proposed activity, identifies the most suitable indicators for each activity, recommends modalities of assistance, shows the reference cost, and provides instructions for ensuring coherence in activity reporting among different partners. This document does not replace the Shelter Cluster technical guidance and should be read together with those.

2. Objectives

Below are the objectives framing the activities included in the HNRP 2024. Strategic objectives are common to all sectors, whereas cluster-specific objectives pertain to shelter and NFI sector activities.

Strategic Objective SO1: Provide principled and timely multi-sectoral lifesaving assistance to internally displaced people, non-displaced people, and returnees, ensuring their safety and dignity.

Cluster Objective CO1: Provide life-saving shelter and Non-food item (NFI) support to conflict-affected IDPs, returnees, and non-displaced people.

Cluster Objective CO2: Deliver emergency shelter and NFI assistance mitigating the impacts of harsh winter weather for IDPs, returnees, and non-displaced people while minimizing environmental impact.

Strategic Objective SO2: Enable access to basic services for internally displaced people, non-displaced people, and returnees.

Cluster Objective CO3: Ensure adequate housing solutions for IDPs, Returnees, and non-displaced people while fostering linkages to longer-term response.

4. Geographical Context

The context determines which activities and forms of assistance are most appropriate. The nature of the crisis is geographically specific. As such, four different zones have been established to frame the expected intervention in each location.

Context 1 refers to areas that are regularly attacked and, therefore, require emergency activities. While there are attacks all over the country, these are locations where attacks are recurrent, access to infrastructure and services is affected, and normal life is severely disrupted. It corresponds to the front line and the Russian border oblasts. The area within 20 kilometers of the Russian border and within 30 kilometers of the front line is considered high-risk and deserves special attention. Context 2 refers to areas receiving displaced people from other locations that require an effort by the authorities and humanitarian agencies to provide shelter and services. Services and housing stock, although functional, are under stress due to increased demand. This situation occurs in virtually every Oblast of the country. Context 3 pertains to areas where the Government of Ukraine (GoU) is regaining control. These are regions that have been under occupation and on the frontlines of war, where infrastructure and services have been severely affected. The remaining population has endured highly challenging conditions, and returning residents struggle to regain access to housing, services, and livelihoods. Context 4 refers to areas not under government control, where humanitarian access is extremely limited, needs assessment capacity is very low, markets are non-functional, and last-mile distribution poses a challenge.
---
5. Targeting, Prioritization & Vulnerabilities

For operational purposes and as a guideline and recommendation for the partners, Shelter Cluster outlines the recommended principles for targeting and prioritization in this chapter.

Targeting approaches Humanitarian assistance can be delivered through either a blanket or a targeted approach1. Shelter Cluster demonstrates an example of a standard procedure for targeting as a decision tree in Annex A. To achieve a targeted approach, four key components contribute to appropriately prioritized targeting: Geographical Prioritization, Preconditions, Activity Specific Vulnerability, and Individual/Household Vulnerabilities. This chapter aims to define each of these components.

Geographical Prioritization A variety of geographical factors can affect the prioritization of activities chosen for that location. For example, limited access, proximity to conflict zones, or onset emergencies following attacks can all impact the process. Ukraine Cash and Voucher Assistance for Health Framework 1.0

1.

Introduction

In the 2024 Ukraine Humanitarian Needs & Response Plan (HNRP), the Health Cluster identified 7.8 million individuals, including IDPs, returnees and non-displaced people in need of humanitarian health assistance including Mental Health support. Of these, 3.8 million people were targeted for assistance in the southern, eastern, and northern oblasts bordering the front line. Along with service delivery, and the procurement and distribution of medicines and supplies, cash and voucher assistance has been one of the accepted modalities of providing health assistance by health partners as stated in the HNRP.

Since the launch of the HNRP in December 2023, air strikes have intensified in areas nearest the frontline and those bordering the Russian Federation. As of January 2024 the humanitarian crisis in Ukraine has worsened significantly. Waves of attacks have had a devastating impact on the health and well-being of civilians, disrupting critical services for hundreds of thousands of people at the peak of winter. Throughout this period, areas originally targeted for humanitarian assistance in regions including Kharkivska, Khersonska, Kyivska, Mykolaivska, Odeska, and Zaporizhzhia have been heavily affected, and people continue struggling to access basic services, intensifying the demand for humanitarian aid.

From Jan – Mar 2024, some 9,700 attacks were recorded.1 As of 09 April 2024, official records documented 31,366 civilian casualties.2 Ongoing attacks on health facilities and schools have had profound consequences, severely hindering access to essential healthcare other basic services. The May 2024 offensive in Donetska, Kharkivska, Khersonska, Sumska oblasts, has resulted in further displacement as civilians are fleeing to safety. As partners respond, the need to provide guidance on the use of Cash and Vouchers in health has become acute as a result of the increased vulnerability of the people in need.

The Ukrainian Health System

Humanitarian actors in Ukraine operate in a space where emergency health services are offered in tandem with national health services. These services vary in availability and accessibility depending on local conflict dynamics. In Ukraine, citizens are guaranteed a package of health services provided at no charge at the point of delivery according to the constitution. Within the national health system, the Ministry of Health (MOH) develops and approves quality standards/clinical protocols, while issuing licenses to those engaged in health care service delivery, the production and sale of medicines and equipment. Within the scope of the Law on State Financial Guarantees of Health Care, the National Health Service of Ukraine (NHSU) purchases packages of services (Program of Medical Guarantees). Each facility then contracts for the services they have the capacity to provide, and for which they must meet contract requirements and specifications defined by the NHSU for each specific package of services. Currently, the NHSU pays for all services, provided these are recorded in the eHealth system, without imposing any service caps or waiting times, and according to the tariffs and payment methods defined in the Cabinet of Ministers Resolution regarding the PMG for the given year.

The main component of the health system reform has been the strengthening of primary health care. Ukrainians can choose a family doctor, pediatrician or general practitioner at any health facility across the country that has a contract with the NHSU. Patients enter into a contract with the chosen doctor by signing a Patient Declaration Form.3 The declaration is an application form that confirms that the patient is being served by the chosen physician and is funded for care as per the PMG at the health

Ukraine Situation Report. Last updated 24 May 2024 (OCHA). UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission in Ukraine (HRMMU) Ministry of Health Ukraine.
---
facility where the physician works. This contract enables doctors to diagnose, treat, write prescriptions for medicines (including those that are included in the Affordable Medicines Program (AMP), and refer patients for specialist care. Primary health care providers are reimbursed per capitation, adjusted for age and terrain, for the number of patients registered with them, as well may receive additional financing for meeting specific vaccination and NCD related indicators. Since 2019, once a physician reaches a specified optimal number of individuals with declarations (family doctor – 1800 declarations, pediatrician – 900 declarations and therapist– 2000 declarations), the NHSU pays a lower capitation rate for any additional person to mitigate the risk of oversized patient panels.

While the MOH and NHSU have continued to function throughout the war – not stopping services or payment for a single day, the overall functionality of the health system, has been impacted by attacks on health care and critical infrastructure, lack of medicines in pharmacies, rising costs of medicines, health care worker shortages in frontline communities, and issues with transport.4 To respond to the war related strains on the health system, adjustments have been made to the services covered in the PMG and medicines included in the AMP. For example, in 2022 additional services such as providing mental health care at the PHC level and providing complex rehabilitation services were included in the PMG. With regards to the AMP, the program now accepts paper-based prescriptions and allows internally displaced patients to receive medications without obtaining a new prescription or receiving a prescription from a PHC doctor who they do not have a declaration signed with. Recently, the NHSU broadened the AMP to include painkillers for palliative care patients, immunosuppressive drugs and test strips for determining blood glucose levels in type I diabetes.5 In 2024, the AMP will further expand to include additional medicines for the treatment of mental health conditions. To increase access to medicines, mobile pharmacies were launched in rural and frontline communities in Cherkasy, Kharkivska, Mykolaivksa, Kyivska, and Chernihivska regions. A pilot project "Ukrposhta.Pharmacy", launched to enable people to receive medicines by mail in Chernihivska, Donetska, Kharkivska, Khersonska Mykolaivska, Sumska, and Zaporizhzhia regions.6

Service availability and gaps

Despite innovations to address wartime strains on the health system, challenges still remain regarding the provision of Universal Health Care, ensuring that everyone can access their right to health care when needed. In frontline oblasts, health care is impeded by security constraints, transport, and infrastructural challenges.

Since the escalation of the war in 2022, the Health Cluster team through the WHO Surveillance System for Attacks on Health Care has verified 1,814 attacks on health care in Ukraine as of June 2024, with 143 deaths and 342 injuries to health care workers and patients. Attacks on health care deprive vulnerable populations of urgently needed care, undermine health systems, and endanger long-term public health goals.

A recent WHO survey conducted in the frontline areas of Dnipro, Donetska, Kharkivska, Khersonska, Mykolaivska, Odeska, and Zaporizhzhia found that approximately 10% of the population lacked consistent access to primary healthcare services (10% in June 2023, 9% in September 2023). Households with members having chronic conditions and children reported even greater difficulties, with 16% experiencing access issues. The primary challenge for those with chronic conditions was financial barriers to treatment, medication, and diagnostics, affecting 42% of this group. The cost of services increased as a barrier from 29% in June to 37% in September 2023. Although the majority of respondents (87%) reported having access to pharmacies within a 30-minute walk, 10% faced challenges in obtaining medicines, primarily due to availability issues (41%).

---
The most recent round of data collection in April 2024 (results not yet published) revealed improvements in access to primary healthcare, with only 6% unable to reach a family doctor. However, 19% of those with chronic conditions still faced access issues, up slightly from 16% in December 2023, with financial constraints remaining the main barrier. Pharmacy access remained stable since December 2023, but access to medicines improved over the last three months, increasing from 16% to 25%. Nonetheless, 9% still faced issues, primarily due to price and availability. Additionally, 16% of respondents experienced problems obtaining prescribed medicines in April 2024, with cost (26%) and availability (19%) being the main barriers.

Cash and voucher assistance for health in tandem with supply side inputs to the health system through humanitarian health action has the potential to reduce financial barriers (and mostly for the vulnerable groups), there is an opportunity to use this modality in addressing health outcomes and reducing costs to accessing health services. Positioning Sectoral Cash and Voucher Assistance in Health

Several assessment findings have highlighted an increase in household expenditures on health (mostly related to the purchase of medicines) since the 2022 escalation of the war. This is evidenced by the 2nd round of the Multi-Sector Needs Analysis (MSNA, 2023), the WHO Health Needs Assessment (HNA 3), and other surveys repeated to gauge population’s perceptions on health and barriers to services, including financial ones.

The Ukraine humanitarian response has followed up commitments put forth in the Grand Bargain to prioritize cash assistance where possible. Although assessments highlight beneficiary preferences for cash, there’s no guarantee that recipients will use the health portion of Multi-Purpose Cash assistance (MPCA) to meet health needs. MPCA cash is unrestricted and can be used for other household needs and services prioritized by the beneficiary. Furthermore, health needs can be costly, unpredictable, and thus challenging to be met through recurrent MPC payments. Allegations of corruption from both out- of-pocket and informal payments in health only reinforce cash in health as a sensitive topic.

To provide guidance and organize the implementation of cash and voucher assistance in health, the Health Cluster is adopting a sector-specific approach to inform the process, taking into account the challenges which exist while capping the volume of emergency (HNRP) support, which can be implemented using a voucher approach. Sectoral cash and voucher assistance in health shouldn’t disrupt regular functioning of the health system but should complement it with a clear phase-out strategy incorporated during the planning process.

Ukraine CVA for Health Framework conceptual model

The Ukraine CVA for Health Framework is informed by the Tanahashi framework, a conceptual model used in public health to assess bottlenecks and improve access to health care services. The framework identifies five dimensions that contribute to health care access: availability, accessibility, affordability, acceptability, and quality. Figure 1 demonstrates how CVA for health can remove the barriers individuals might face in accessing health care services in areas affected by the war.

The complexity of health services delivery in front line and hard-to-reach areas demonstrates the need to consider integrated programming, in which CVA is considered complementary to supply side and government health financing rather than a replacement. Integrated programming acknowledges that health outcomes are influenced by a multitude of factors beyond access to health care services. Cash and voucher assistance can help address socio-economic determinants of health, such as lack of transportation, which may hinder an individual’s ability to effectively seek and use health care services.

2. Medication/health service selection with oblast health authorities Partner pre-engagement prerequisites

The choice of health services to be covered as part of the CVA programming in health should be informed by evidence. The examination of available secondary sources of information to confirm/affirm the need for such services (as well as their relevance) should be conducted. Some readily available sources include; MoH health statistics, HeRAMs, PHSA, MSNA, different health assessments among others, which incorporate information on the health gaps.

A more detailed contextual assessment (by a partner) to deepen the body of available information while zooming in on the problem to confirm its’ relevance in the contemporary moment should be conducted. The focus of such an assessment should not rely solely on gaps related to the investigated problem but examine opportunities which can be seized to contribute to finding solutions. Such opportunities could relate to existing frameworks/services within and outside the public sector. Situational analyses should also incorporate aspects relating to social determinants affecting the availability and accessibility of desired health services.

Findings from the review of secondary data and contextual assessment should be presented to local health authorities and CVA for Health Task Team with suggestions of how CVA can meet the health needs without disrupting the existing health system. Synergies with existing programs and approaches should be clarified (e.g. CVA facilitating access to medicines should demonstrate how the approach complements Affordable Medicines Program (AMP), Mobile Pharmacy Initiative and UkrPoshta pharmaceutical delivery, etc.). A phase-out approach should be clarified as part of the process.

Determining whether a supply or demand intervention is selected depends on agreements with local health authorities, the number of affected pre-identified patients in the affected population, and distances to the nearest functional health facility or pharmacy.

Although the Health Cluster advocates for a voucher approach (matching beneficiary needs/conditions with services and abstaining from the direct donation of cash), the cluster is aware of varied and critical positions of some cluster partners on this issue. Vouchers in healthcare therefore, must aim at facilitating access to services for a specific pre-identified category of beneficiaries (including vulnerable persons) who would be unable to access these services without such planning. Where patients must travel long distances to access health services, and transport and accommodation represents a barrier, the organization facilitating CVA should make arrangements which favor transportation of patients, while remaining accountable for expenses related to such transportation effort.

3.

Approach, choice of medicines and existing health system

High levels of inaccessibility to medicines and laboratory tests have been flagged during country level assessments, which have informed the Health Cluster’s classification of the severity of health needs for the affected population. These results indicate the inability of those most affected by the war to access health services and medications in front line communities.

In response to these gaps, humanitarian actors have been inclined to facilitate access, enabling health care availability in communities most affected by the war. While partners delve to provide immediate solutions, the approach should aim at fostering the use of mechanisms set by the MoH where available, including facilitating access to the AMP through mobile pharmacies, UkrPoshta and other means. Health partners should encourage patients to access national services provided free-of-charge where the war has not rendered such services damaged or destroyed.

Partners making arrangements should adhere to the following principles:

Promote the use of the Ukrainian AMP pharmacies, UkrPoshta and Government Mobile pharmacies where services are available and not absent due to the war. Primarily encourage the use of medicines provided/mentioned under the above government frameworks. Avoid programming which encourages patient access to medicines outside government frameworks when these or their equivalents are available. Only temporarily cover gaps of services (medicines) not available as part of the government framework, by making arrangements for these using a voucher system with a third-party provider. Such patients should be identified and mapped prior to initiating the health project.
---
Cash assistance to patients to procure medicines themselves should be avoided. Where transportation is required, modalities avoiding direct cash transfer is encouraged and the partner facilitates these using existing transportation networks. Maintain flexibility to accommodate transition to the existing government frameworks at the earliest time possible.

4.

Access to medicines for patients facilitated by CVA health partners should only include those categories and specialties on the Essential Medicines List (EML) of Ukraine, and avoid prohibited medicines. Partners will be required to discuss locally with the local departments of health to provide evidence on the consideration of medicines from the EML list.

Vulnerability and targeting criteria

While all of Ukraine has been affected by the ongoing war, the Cluster’s estimation and analysis of needs shows a decreasing severity of humanitarian needs as the distance from active hostilities increases, while those in the southern, eastern, and northern oblasts bordering the front line are more severe. Amid these populations, certain characteristics can intersect and result in an affected person having less access to health care services.

Below are some common targeting criteria that may intersect, and considerations that health actors may use when designing CVA for health.

Health status: Households in the frontline oblasts targeted by the HNRP experiencing a health need directly or indirectly related to the war. Individual status: The elderly and people with disabilities, who have difficulties in accessing health care, pregnant women children, who are at risk of several health issues, people without documentation in need of health care services.
